item.title: Reading as a Mirror
item.description:
First post of 2026.

For a long time, I avoided books. Not because I disliked learning itself but because books once felt like pressure, and authority to me. What I resisted was not reading but the condition under which it was imposed (and at the time, the material itself).

That shift happened when reading was no longer imposed.

Non-fiction, in particular altered the way I see both the inner and outer world. Not by adding more information but by challenging the lens through which I perceive life. Slowly, it became clear that what we often call “understanding” is nothing more than conditioned thought repeating itself in familiar patterns. And familiarity feels safe to the mind.

item.title: The Untouched Mind
item.description:
Lately, something about kids is moving me. They carry an unconditioned mind, a purity of consciousness.

If they’re angry, the anger is full.
If they’re joyful, the joy is complete.
If they’re curious, the curiosity has no end.

Their innocence isn’t something they learn, it’s what consciousness looks like before it’s shaped by beliefs, identity, conditioning, and inherited thoughts.

As we grow, we accumulate layers of opinions, conditioning, expectations. We stop seeing life directly and begin seeing it through a borrowed lens. The simplicity we were born with gets buried beneath thought, mostly without our awareness.

item.title: Don't Try
item.description:
The moment you resist, you go against the natural flow of existence. When you resist anything or anyone in its true nature, you unknowingly build a cage within the realm of existence and this is where you’ve already lost the game.

Freedom lies in the absence of resistance, and the mantra should be to ’not invest in resistance’. Solitude is found in experiencing the raw, being in tune with it rather than resisting its natural flow.

item.title: The Observer is the Observed
item.description:
People view the world through their own perceptions, and so they see nothing but themselves. There exists one single universal consciousness, within which our minds create our own little distinct identities to perceive the universe on our own terms.

When you become observant of your self and the totality of life, you begin to see how everything is connected and that none of us are truly different. It’s all part of one system.

item.title: I know that I know nothing
item.description:
We unknowingly reject things due to the lack of our understanding of the broader reality they exist within. We must acknowledge the fact that we don’t even know the knowns, let alone the unknowns.

It makes sense why Socrates said:

“I know that I know nothing.”

My reading moves between philosophy, psychology, science, and fiction that reflects human experience.

item.title: Utilizing Github Actions to Serve a tool via Web
item.description:
TL;DR: I employed GitHub Actions to execute a Go utility, essentially utilizing GitHub Actions as a server to serve my Go tool via a Web interface.

Just for fun, I wanted to serve one of my Go tools gh-archive through a web interface. After some thought, I decided to make use of (or exploit) GitHub Actions.

Strategy:

  1. Gather user input through an HTML form (hosted via GitHub pages).
  2. Trigger a dispatch event to create a workflow in GitHub with a unique name.
  3. The GitHub Workflow will perform the tasks of building, running, and saving the output file of the Go program.
  4. Retrieve the list of all workflow and iterate through the JSON results to match the workflow name.
  5. Check the status of that workflow, if it’s completed or not.
  6. If the workflow status is completed, retrieve the downloadable URL of the artifacts, download, and extract them.
  7. Display the content extracted from the output file back to the user.

To execute these steps, I skimmed through the GitHub REST API Documentation to identify the necessary APIs for the tasks at hand.
